headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you for standing by and welcome to the SunTrust Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I will turn the meeting over to K
componenttext: Thank you for standing by and welcome to the SunTrust Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I will turn the meeting over to Kris Dickson, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone and welcome to SunTrust Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us today. In addition to the press release, we have also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during the call today. Th
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone and welcome to SunTrust Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us today. In addition to the press release, we have also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during the call today. The press release presentation and detailed financial schedule are available on our website, www.suntrust.com. This information can be accessed by going to the Investor Relations section of the website. 
With me today, among other members of our executive management team, are Bill Rogers, our Chairman and CEO; Aleem Gillani, our Chief Financial Officer; and Tom Freeman, our Chief Risk Officer. 
Before we get started, I need to remind you that our comments today may include forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties and actual results could differ materially. Factor that might cause actual results to differ materially in our press release and SEC filings, which are available on our website. 
During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures in talking about the company's performance. You can find the reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measures in our press release on our website, www.suntrust.com. Finally, SunTrust is not responsible for and does not edit nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings our conference transcripts provided by third parties. The only authorized live and archived webcasts are located on our website. With that out-of-the-way, I'll turn it over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Kris. On our normal fashion, I will begin today's call with some brief comments on our performance this quarter and then pass on to Aleem to provide details on our results. Our high-level points are showed on our Slide 3 of our presentation.
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Kris. On our normal fashion, I will begin today's call with some brief comments on our performance this quarter and then pass on to Aleem to provide details on our results. Our high-level points are showed on our Slide 3 of our presentation. Our performance continues to steadily improve this quarter. Net income to common shareholders was $270 million and earnings per share of $0.50, a $0.04 increase over last quarter and a $0.17 increase over last year. 
From the revenue side, total revenue was up $28 million over last quarter, driven by higher noninterest income. Strong margins revenue growth $64 million or 7% sequential quarter increase in fee income while our net interest income declined $36 million due to the decrease in swap income. Mortgage production volume remain high this quarter. To date this year, we closed almost $16 billion in mortgage loans, up over 50% from last year which helped over 62,000 clients buy or refinance a home this year including many due to our HARP program. 
Now moving on to expenses. They were stable the last quarter last year. Included in this quarter's expense was a $13 million noncash charge associated with redemption of a $1.2 billion of trust preferred securities. These were higher cost findings and as such, we moved quickly to redeem them once the capital treatment of that occurred allowing us to do so. We made second progress in our efforts to reduce expenses through our PPG program. Today we generated annualized savings of $250 million, and we're now well within our sight of $300 million goal for the program. At the risk of being redundant, I reiterate that we're committed to establishing a more efficiently run organization. The PPG program was the catalyst but was never intended to be the final goal for us. What I'm saying here is when PPG is done, our work is not. The ultimate objective is to getting our efficiency ratio under 60%, and we have high intensity around both revenue and expense initiatives to help us achieve that goal. 
Now taking a look at the balance sheet. Loan growth particularly in C&I drove a $1 billion increase in average performing loan balances over last quarter and nearly a $10 billion increase over last year. At the same time, we've been actively managing down certain real estate related loan balances. Though average client deposits were stable to last quarter's record level, we continue to see the favorable mix shift this quarter. Average DDA balances were up 3% from the prior quarter and 23% from the prior year, while CD balances declined. Credit quality also continued to improve across-the-board. Net charge-offs are 1.14% of average loans, down 17% from the prior quarter. Nonperforming loans were down 7% and early-stage delinquencies declined 7 basis points. Lastly, we generated additional positive capital growth with Tier 1 common ratio estimated at 9.4 at quarter end. Before I wrap up my comments and turn it to Aleem, I'm going to take a minute to address our resubmitted capital plan under the 2012 CCAR process. As you are aware, we submitted our revised capital plan in mid-June. While the Fed is in the process of reviewing our plan come I wanted to share with you in advance of that we elected not to request any increase in the current level of the dividend or any other return of capital at this time. We made this decision in light of the fact that the submission only covered capital actions for the fourth quarter of 2012 and the first quarter of 2013. Additionally, we considered the close proximity of the resubmission to the 2013 CCAR process, which is expected to begin in the fourth quarter of this year shortly after the time we expect to hear back on this plan. We think this is the best course of action for the short-term. It's not indicative of our long-term plans to return capital prudently to shareholders. As a reminder in their review of our original plan submission, the Fed did not object to the trust preferred redemption which I noted earlier have been completed or to maintain the quarterly common stock dividend of $0.05 a share. The 2013 CCAR process, that will begin later this year, will provide us an opportunity to violate capital deployment alternatives for next year. 
So overall, we make continued progress this quarter with momentum building in several key areas of our company. Of note, was the solid noninterest income growth mainly driven by strong mortgage production followed by the pick up in several other the categories as well. We also saw a continuation of a multi-quarter trend in increase performing loan balances, particularly in our C&I book. Looking ahead, challenges remain with a less than ideal operating environment, but I believe SunTrust is well positioned to capitalize upon our opportunities. With that said, let me turn it over to Aleem.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. I will begin my comments this morning on Slide 4. Bill had a lot of the highlights so I will be brief and then we will dig deeper on subsequent slides. As Bill noted earlier, we are pleased to re
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning. Thank you for joining us today. I will begin my comments this morning on Slide 4. Bill had a lot of the highlights so I will be brief and then we will dig deeper on subsequent slides. As Bill noted earlier, we are pleased to report higher earnings per share this quarter of $0.50, which is a $0.04 increase from the prior quarter and $0.17 increase from last year. This sequential quarter income growth is attributable to high revenue and lower loan loss provision. Revenue grew $28 million as higher noninterest income more than offset the swap-related decline in net interest income. Provision declined $17 million with the lower net charge-offs and continued improvement in other credit metrics. Higher revenue and a lower loan loss provision also drove the growth from the second quarter of last year. Revenue increased by $48 million by a combination of higher net interest income and higher fee income. The latter of which was primarily mortgage related. 
Improvements in credit quality were widespread, providing a $92 million decline in the provision, while noninterest expense was essentially unchanged. Year-to-date EPS was $0.96. This is more than double the $0.41 reported during the first 6 months of last year. Revenue was higher, up 2% on a reported basis, by a more meaningful 5% net of the usual quarterly adjustment items we detailed in the appendix. Other drivers were lower loan loss provision and the redemption of the capital purchase program for preferred shares. Let's take a look at each of the major income statement categories, beginning with net interest income on Slide 5. On a sequential quarter basis, net interest income declined by $36 million or 3%, and the net interest margin fell by 10 basis points to 3.39%. Both of these declines were almost entirely due to the previously disclosed reduction in income for maturing commercial loan loss. Excluding the impact of the swap, net interest income and margin were relatively stable as lower loan yields and a smaller securities portfolio offset by the benefits of higher loan balances and and improved deposit mix. 
Despite lower swap income, net interest income increased from the prior year by $20 million or 2%. Interest income declined by $49 million as lower asset yield outweighed the favorable impact of higher loan balances. However, this was more than offset by a $69 million decline in interest expense, driven by favorable liability trends, including strong DDA growth, a 17 basis point reduction in deposit rates paid, and a 65 basis point decline in long-term debt cost. 
I'll spend a few minutes discussing that some of the major drivers of future net interest income and margin. First on the asset side, with a slightly improving economy, we expect to see continued long growth, which would be additive to net interest income. Although as you're well aware, most going on rates are lower than the portfolio's current yield. The securities balance declined somewhat this quarter as we didn't see many attractive alternatives in light of the continued decline in yields. We will continue to monitor the market, and we'll pick our spots to reinvest. 
Commercial loan swap income is expected to stay relatively stable through the next year at its current level of about $120 million per quarter, assuming no major changes to LIBOR. 
Turning to the liability side, during the third quarter, we'll begin to benefit from last week's redemption of $1.2 billion in higher cost trust preferred securities, which had a weighted average cost of about 7%. Positive pricing opportunities are obviously becoming limited at this point given their low absolute rates. This is something that we do continue to evaluate and manage carefully. We will also benefit from higher cost CDs maturing and rolling into lower rate products. All told there are headwinds and tailwinds. As we look specifically to the third quarter, we expect those headwinds and tailwinds to largely offset one another such as that the net interest margin is relatively stable. 
Look at noninterest income on Slide 6. Noninterest income was $940 million, a sequential quarter increase of $64 million on a reported basis or $39 million net of the adjusted items we detailed in the appendix. Mortgage production income was strong this quarter as our origination volumes and gains on sale remain high. 
During the quarter, we closed over $8.2 billion of loans, which was up 8%. Purchase volume was $3 billion, an increase of over $1 billion. Refinance volume declined modestly but remains healthy at $5.2 billion. Mortgage production income was $103 million this quarter or $258 million exclusive of the mortgage repurchase provision. Sequential quarter growth and the reported figure was $40 million, $20 million of which was attributable to a lower repurchase provision and $18 million due to a gain in conjunction with the sale of a portfolio containing government guaranteed mortgages. I'll discuss about of those in more detail in subsequent slides. 
In addition to the increase in mortgage production, we saw growth in numerous other consumer and commercial fee categories. As a couple of examples, loan commitment fees recorded in the other charges and fees line items were strong and card fees grew due to increased client usage. Relative to the prior year, noninterest income was up $28 million on a reported basis and $59 million or 7% on an adjusted basis. The largest driver of the adjusted fee growth was a $99 million increase in mortgage production. The core mortgage production income up $164 million, partially offset by a $65 million increase in the repurchase provision. Fee income was also a driver of the year-over-year growth due to improved market conditions. On the flip side, card fees declined due to the implementation of caps on debit change income. We also saw a decline in investment banking income on lower syndicated finance volumes. 
Let's turn to Slide 7 for a discussion of this quarter's trends in mortgage repurchases. Mortgage repurchase demand show on the top left box were $489 million this quarter. That's an increase of about $40 million from last quarter but within a range of expectations and well below the elevated levels we saw in the fourth quarter of last year. Demand continue to be concentrated in the 2006 to 2008 vintages which have accounted for roughly 90% of all demand activity over the past several years, as well as this quarter. While demand levels may remain elevated in the coming quarters, consistent with what we have expressed for several quarters now, the underlying trends in demands and full power requests continue to suggest to us that the agencies are making progress and working through these higher loss content vintages. For example, full file requests volume has moderated somewhat and continue to transition toward loans that are delinquent but not yet in foreclosure. 
Pending population, shown on the top right portion of the slide increased to $652 million, up roughly $90 million from the prior quarter. This was the result of the increase in new demands as well as a slower income demand resolution. We're taking a deliberate approach to the demand review process, ensuring that we repurchase loans where appropriate yet cure or moderate losses wherever possible. Mortgage repurchase reserve, shown at the bottom left of the page, increased to $434 million, up $51 million from the first quarter. The increase relates primarily to the higher level of the pending population. Said differently, the reserve increase is in part due to the higher level of demands and in part, the reduction in charge-offs, which is merely a function of loss recognition time. Similar to prior quarters some summary statistics of our sold mortgages are displayed at the bottom right of this page, and we've also provided some additional detail on the 2006 to 2008 vintages in the appendix. Overall, I'd note that our expectations around mortgage repurchases remain generally unchanged from what we've shared with you in recent quarters. We foresee demand volume remaining high and variable in the coming quarters. However, if recent patterns and full power requests continue as anticipated, we expect to see a reduced income statement impact towards the end of this year. 
Let's move on to expenses on Slide 8. Expenses were essentially stable to both the prior quarter and prior year. On a sequential quarter basis, employee compensation and benefits declined by $35 million due to seasonal reduction in benefits. This decline was offset by growth in a handful of other categories. Bill mentioned earlier the $13 million noncash charge that we incurred related to the redemption of trust preferred securities. Additionally, operating losses increased $9 million due to specific mortgage related losses and legal accruals. FDIC premiums increased $8 million. This line item was a bit lower than normal in the first quarter and the Q2 level is expected to meet a more normal run rate. 
In credit related expenses, which we detailed for you as usual in the appendix, increased by $7 million. Bill point out that this quarter we refined our methodology by recognizing tax payments on dividend and loans, which resulted in an approximate $10 million increase in credit collection expense. As a result of this change, we should not experience the seasonal fourth quarter spike in this line item that we've seen in prior years. Relative to the prior year, adjusted the expenses declined $11 million, driven by lower FDIC premiums, credit-related expenses and marketing costs. These declines were partially offset by a modest increase in compensation and higher outside processing costs. 
Before we turn to the balance sheet, starting on Slide 9, I will summarize this quarters income statement by noting that we drove continued improvement in our core earning this quarter. Obviously, our absolute level of profitability is still well below our profit generation capability. But overall, we are pleased to note the continued progression towards a more normalized level of earnings. Average performing loans increased again this quarter, up sequentially by a little over $1 billion or about 1%. The growth was driven by commercial loans, specifically C&I, which was up $1.3 billion. Within our wholesale businesses, both continued to be concentrated in larger corporate clients and to be well diversified. Specific industry verticals within our corporate investment bank that drove the bulk of this quarter's growth were health care, diversified, financial services and media. Also bought some modest growth in our Diversified Commercial Banking business driven by auto dealers and not-for-profit clients. While we saw a continued runoff of legacy assets in our commercial real estate, the phase of decline moderated again this quarter. 
The residential portfolio was relatively stable this quarter. Within that, we grew non-guaranteed loans by about $700 million driven by high FICO jumbo loans. That guaranteed portfolio was down approximately $600 million, partially due to the sale of $0.5 billion in loans this quarter. 
Relative to the prior year, performing loans grew almost $10 billion or 9% with the growth coming entirely from our targeted categories, namely C&I, guaranteed mortgages and consumer loans. C&I led the way, up $5.6 million or 12%, driven by large corporate and middle market borrowers. Consumer loans increased to almost $4 billion or 24% with growth across all loan categories most notably student loans. In government guaranteed mortgages we're up $1.5 billion or about 33%. 
The overall portfolio growth was partially offset by intentional declines in certain portfolios, including CRE, construction and home equity, which were managed down by a combined $2.3 billion. The continued impact of this de-risking is evident on Slide 10. The portfolios that we've categorized as higher risks declined by $14 billion or 60% over the past few years, and they were down by another $400 million this quarter. Higher risk balances were managed down by over $2 billion or 18% from the prior year. The decline split relatively evenly between the 3 major categories. This can be seen on the bottom of the page. The overall decline and the higher risk balances over the last 2 years has essentially been offset by increases in government guaranteed loans. This combination has helped to significantly improve the risk profile of the company in a relatively short period of time. Additionally, the increases in government guaranteed balances also served as a bridge at the time of organic loan growth. These quarters higher risk loan balances have declined at a slower pace in the light of the smaller size of this portfolio and its improving risk. Additionally, we've seen a pick-up in organic loan demand. As such and as part of our continued active management of the balance sheet, we elected to sell about $0.5 billion of government guaranteed mortgages this quarter and this resulted in an $18 million gain. 
Let's turn to Slide 11 for a review of credit quality. Credit quality continued to trend favorably this quarter with meaningful declines in delinquencies, nonperforming assets, nonperforming loans and net charge-offs. Early-stage delinquencies, excluding government guaranteed loans, were down by 8 basis points from the prior quarter, driven by residential loans. Non-guaranteed mortgage delinquency rates declined by 23 basis points and home equity improved by 11 basis points. Nonperforming loans declined sequentially by almost $200 million or 7%. Improvements were evident across the portfolio, most notably in commercial real estate and residential and commercial construction. Nonperforming assets declined by over $300 million or 11%, driven by the decline in nonperforming loans, as well as reductions in other real estate owned and the completion of the sale of the nonperforming mortgage loans we commenced last quarter. Year-over-year, nonperforming loans were down $1.2 billion or more than 30%. All loan categories showed improvement with the highest declines coming from commercial construction, CRE and C&I. 
Net charge-offs declined by $72 million or 17% sequentially, and the net charge-off ratio fell by 24 basis points to 1.14%. Non-guaranteed mortgages, home equity and Commercial Real Estate were the biggest drivers of the improvement. Relative to the prior year, net charge-offs were lower by $155 million or about 30% with meaningful improvements seen across most of the portfolios. 
Allowance for loan and lease losses was $2.3 billion at quarter end or 1.86% of loans. In light of the continued favorable trends in credit quality, the allowance declined this quarter, albeit at a more modest pace than recent quarters. Excluding government guaranteed loans from the denominator of the allowance calculation, the ratio stood at 2.07%. Overall, we were pleased with our trends and credit metrics and the improvements exceeded our expectations, particularly in net charge-offs. As we look forward, our recovering economy should continue to support our positive asset quality trend with improvements primarily driven by the residential portfolio as most of the commercial and consumer portfolios are currently nearing more normal credit metric level. 
Looking specifically at the third quarter, we currently expect to see additional declines in nonperforming loans and relatively stable net charge-offs. 
Let's take a look at deposit performance. Average deposit balances were stable at their record first quarter level of approximately $126 billion. The favorable shift in deposit mix continued as DDA and savings increased by higher cost time deposits decline. Compared to last year, client deposits were up $4 billion or 3%. Lower cost deposits drove the increase with DDA up almost $7 billion or 23%. Conversely, time deposits were down almost $3 billion or 14%. This favorable mix shift has contributed to our year-over-year net interest income growth. 
Slide 13 provides information on our capital metrics. Tier 1 common increased for the eighth consecutive quarter, up sequentially by approximately $300 million primarily from increased retained earnings. Tier 1 common ratio ended the quarter at an estimated 9.4%, up another 7 basis points from last quarter's 9.33%. While not shown on this slide, I'll mention the capital impact of our decision to call the $1.2 billion of higher cost trust preferred securities. Redemption of the securities resulted in a reduction of our Basel I Tier 1 ratio, about 90 basis points and that impact is already reflected in our second quarter capital ratio estimates. As you are aware, this will not impact our fully Basel III Tier 1 ratio as trust preferreds are not Tier 1 qualifying instruments. As it relates to our recent Basel III notice of proposed rule making, we continue to evaluate the potential impact to our capital ratios. Under this proposal, we expect to see some increase in risk weighted assets and a corresponding decrease in capital ratios, primarily due to the ranges of risk ratings for residential mortgages and home equity. We've implemented as stated in the recent NPR, our resulting capital ratios that should still comfortably exceed all proposed regulatory requirements. 
Bottom part of this slide shows our tangible common equity ratio and our tangible book value per share. Book were up this quarter due to increases in retained earnings and other comments of income. Tangible common equity ratio increased by 17 basis points to 8.15%, while our tangible book value per share declined about 2% to end the quarter at just about $26. 
Let's turn to Slide 14 for a discussion of our Playbook for Profitable Growth expense program. As you can see, we made continued progress against the $300 million expense savings goal for the PPG program. To date, we've reached $250 million in annualized savings. As you know, this program is comprised of numerous expense savings initiatives, broken into 3 main buckets, strategic supply management, consumer bank efficiencies and operations and support staff. This quarter, we garnered savings in each of the category. And on this slide, you can see the activities that were the primary drivers of the savings. 
On our strategic supply management initiatives, we achieved additional savings through further contract renegotiations. Additionally, we have successfully managed down our own spending on items we consider discretionary, items such as travel, print and wireless service. Our teammates are finding ways everyday to cut out expenses for things that once seemed necessity. There's a high level of commitment here throughout the company and this is something every teammate can do to improve efficiency and meet our goals. 
On the consumer bank efficiencies category, we achieved savings primarily due to 2 key initiatives. First, we revamped our branch staffing model to better align market needs with staff from both the capabilities and a volume perspective. We're achieving greater efficiencies by differentiating staffing by client segments served and market opportunities. Furthermore, we changed our incentive compensation structure for certain types of positions and this is now yielding real dollar savings. Several initiatives have driven our operations and support staff savings. But the chief component of our savings this quarter came from tighter spend in layers with further reduction in FTEs. We also made additional progress in our efforts to leverage digital technologies, taking significant reductions and the number of paper statements that we now process. We are rapidly approaching our goal of $300 million in savings. 
As Bill mentioned earlier, this by no means should imply that we are done with our work here. PPG was the beginning of a process of transformation of SunTrust. We will continue to leverage the strong momentum we have generated and drive toward our ultimate goal of a sub-60% efficiency ratio upon the abatement of elevated credit and mortgage related expenses. PPG program is only the start of our efficiency improvement efforts. That wraps up my comments for today. So I will turn the call back over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Aleem. And before we move into Q&A, I'd like to take a few moments to highlight some of the progress we have been making in our lines of business. These results punctuated the core momentum we are building. I will start by noting that the ef
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Aleem. And before we move into Q&A, I'd like to take a few moments to highlight some of the progress we have been making in our lines of business. These results punctuated the core momentum we are building. I will start by noting that the efficiency ratio is down are each of the lines of business relative to last quarter last year. Of course, their absolute levels are too high. Each business has specific plans aimed at driving continued improvements. In our consuming banking and private while line of business, we generated solid DDA growth of 11% and loan production volume was up a healthy 19% during the first half of the year. From a revenue perspective and the regulatory headwinds continue to challenge noninterest income in this business, however, you'll notice that expenses were down 7% from the second quarter last year due in large part to reductions in staffing driven by our PPG initiatives which Aleem highlighted. Another encouraging statistic is that client loyalty continue to increase in our retail business this quarter solidifying our position as an industry leading bank and our footprint for this metric. Also of note here is our credit card business. The relaunch of this business is in its early stages, but it is going well thus far. account sales more than 4x the levels generated in the second quarter of last year. We've been delivering strong results in our wholesale business. Year-to-date net income was nearly double what it was a year ago. We saw a record net income and revenue in corporate investment banking. It generated the lion's share of the 8% wholesale loan growth over last year. DDA balances were up 24% driven by our diversified commercial banking business. We're also beginning to generate some core commercial real estate growth. Like credit card, we're in early stages here, but we're pleased with our progress and believe commercial real estate loan balances are nearing an inflection point where we start to see some growth in this portfolio in the coming quarters. We are also seeing improving trends in our mortgage line of business. Year-to-date mortgage production volume was up $5.5 billion or over 50% and core mortgage production income was $320 million higher. The overall profitability of our mortgage business continues to be negatively impacted by legacy issues and still operating a net loss position this quarter if the trends are improving. Given the current rate environment and some overall improvements in the housing market, coupled with the HARP pipeline, we expect our near-term mortgage production revenue to remain strong. So overall, line of business performance is trending positively, and we are seeing the results more clearly and the company's financial metrics. SunTrust team is working hard in delivering better results and I'd be remiss in not recognizing them and thanking them for their collective effort. With that said, Kris, let me turn it back over to you.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Candy, we're ready to start the Q&A. [Operator Instructions] .
componenttext: Candy, we're ready to start the Q&A. [Operator Instructions] .

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Bill Pancari from Evercore Partners.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some more color your decision to not request deployment as to the CCAR resubmission? Was it influenced by the Basel III NPR? I know you didn't give us the basis point impact but that would be helpful as well on Tier 1 common.
componenttext: Can you give us some more color your decision to not request deployment as to the CCAR resubmission? Was it influenced by the Basel III NPR? I know you didn't give us the basis point impact but that would be helpful as well on Tier 1 common.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Bill. I'll take the first crack on that. First of all, it was not influenced by Basel III. I think sort of in its simplest form I mean the resubmission gave us 2 more quarters of better performance late into 2013 gives us 4 quarters of continued p
componenttext: This is Bill. I'll take the first crack on that. First of all, it was not influenced by Basel III. I think sort of in its simplest form I mean the resubmission gave us 2 more quarters of better performance late into 2013 gives us 4 quarters of continued performance. And you've seen we're on a steady trend. That might ought to give some indication of our competence. So it was more just continued to wait for the company's performance to improve both on the income side and the credit metrics side, not actually more complicated than that.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So do you have the basis point impact from the Basel III NPR changes?
componenttext: Okay. So do you have the basis point impact from the Basel III NPR changes?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me take a swing at that.
componenttext: Let me take a swing at that.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me take a crack at that. First of all I think I've got to say we were pleased to see the NPR. Having that out I think is going to give more clarity to the industry as capital expected capital ratios are going to look like going forward. Having said th
componenttext: Let me take a crack at that. First of all I think I've got to say we were pleased to see the NPR. Having that out I think is going to give more clarity to the industry as capital expected capital ratios are going to look like going forward. Having said that, parts of the NPR came as a little bit of a surprise. On the numerator side, this came out pretty well as much as the industry expected. But on the denominator side, some of the changes RWA for example, were not expected. And HARP actually part of the Basel II proposal these are U.S. regulatory proposals. We are along with the rest of the industry responding to that proposal now and I think the industry has a deadline sometime September  to respond back to that. At that point the regulators will take a look at all the response letter sent come out with final rules at some point probably next year. As we try to estimate what we might look like under this proposal, I think you've seen a lot of banks over the last few days estimate that their final numbers are going to be in the 8% range using these proposals on our current portfolios and prior management litigation. And I think it would be fairer as you look at our portfolio to say we will come in around the same kind of level as most of the banks are estimating.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Levin, Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Levin, Citigroup.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Given how challenging the rate environment is for all the banks, one of your peers yesterday said it was going to close up to 5% of its branches. As you think about the environment, rates and regulatory costs and how you want to drive costs down, are you
componenttext: Given how challenging the rate environment is for all the banks, one of your peers yesterday said it was going to close up to 5% of its branches. As you think about the environment, rates and regulatory costs and how you want to drive costs down, are you considering branch closings or some kind of infrastructure reduction in order to save costs?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think I would put it more in the category of just general efficiencies and particularly in the consumer banking area. I mean if you look at what we've done, expenses being down 7% there, that's a combination of just being efficient. Clearly, transaction
componenttext: I think I would put it more in the category of just general efficiencies and particularly in the consumer banking area. I mean if you look at what we've done, expenses being down 7% there, that's a combination of just being efficient. Clearly, transaction volumes and branches are down. Nobody is sort of missing that. I'm a believer in that branch is a sales center as much as it is a service center. So physically having people there on the sales side is a benefit. Whether we close a few branches or open a few branches, we will sort of be netting around that number. We'll look at that as a consideration long term, but the real efficiency just is what we do within the branch. And you're already starting to see that from us. I mean I think we're sort of ahead of the game in that front.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Some of your peers have suggested that over the last few weeks given the macro uncertainty, customers are becoming a bit more reticent investing in the businesses. Are you hearing that or sensing that from your customers when you're out in the field
componenttext: Okay. Some of your peers have suggested that over the last few weeks given the macro uncertainty, customers are becoming a bit more reticent investing in the businesses. Are you hearing that or sensing that from your customers when you're out in the field?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's sort of a tale of two cities. I mean you see what is going on with our loan growth, particularly on the upper end side. Our pipelines on the commercial side are actually quite strong and ahead of where they were significantly this time last year. But
componenttext: It's sort of a tale of two cities. I mean you see what is going on with our loan growth, particularly on the upper end side. Our pipelines on the commercial side are actually quite strong and ahead of where they were significantly this time last year. But if you're out there and I'm out there a lot and you talk primarily sort of on the small business side. Yes, I think there's a lot of uncertainty and all the things that could cause that uncertainty from fiscal '12 to tax to health care, all of the things that we're concerned about. And you see it in the cash buildout. But having, despite all that, we're still seeing some loan growth.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Mutascio, Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Mutascio, Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Aleem, if you can walk me through something, I would appreciate it. On Slide 14, you talked about the cost saves that you realized about $250 million of the $300 million that you have planned for. But I then I go to Slide 26 in the presentation and look a
componenttext: Aleem, if you can walk me through something, I would appreciate it. On Slide 14, you talked about the cost saves that you realized about $250 million of the $300 million that you have planned for. But I then I go to Slide 26 in the presentation and look at your own adjusted quarter noninterest expense. And on a year-over-year basis, you're only down $10 million. I would expect the quarterly number to be down more like $60 million or a quarter of the $250 million of savings that you've gotten already. So I guess my question is where are the cost savings coming?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Of course, let me help you a little bit with that. There've been cost saves pretty well across the board. There've been cost saves for example, in compensation and cost saves in areas discretionary expenses. And as you go down our income statement, those
componenttext: Of course, let me help you a little bit with that. There've been cost saves pretty well across the board. There've been cost saves for example, in compensation and cost saves in areas discretionary expenses. And as you go down our income statement, those cost saves have showed up pretty well along the way on the line. However, some of those have been offset by cost increases in some other areas. For example, we've got some consulting costs for now that have come in as a result of the mortgage foreclosure review that were not originally anticipated. So you'll see some of those in there. And you will see some compensation increases as a result of increased revenue. And so just as a result of revenue related compensation increases, we've got some increases there. And so that's why overall, you see a netting. That netting is I would consider that to be a really good trade and that we are paying people commissions on revenue they're generating while at the same time, we're reducing core costs.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean if you put some -- this is Bill. If you put some numbers around that, just think of the 2 businesses that are most highly correlated to compensation and mortgage and CIB over year-over-year comparison, they're up about $250 million and about $50 mi
componenttext: I mean if you put some -- this is Bill. If you put some numbers around that, just think of the 2 businesses that are most highly correlated to compensation and mortgage and CIB over year-over-year comparison, they're up about $250 million and about $50 million of comp. I think that's a pretty good trade-off. Similarly, our core revenue is up about 5% and core expenses are up about 1.5%. So those are driving us towards that lower efficiency ratio. Do want it to be faster, are we still frustrated by the level of expenses, absolutely excuse making category. But some of these trade-offs as it relates to revenue and comp I think are worth making.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question from Jefferson Harralson, KBW.
componenttext: Our next question from Jefferson Harralson, KBW.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to discuss this 60% efficiency ratio goal and what needs to happen to get there. So the rest of the PPG assume all credit collections, do you needs or some percentage of credit collections and credit related expenses, do you need to have a better m
componenttext: I want to discuss this 60% efficiency ratio goal and what needs to happen to get there. So the rest of the PPG assume all credit collections, do you needs or some percentage of credit collections and credit related expenses, do you need to have a better margin or better operating environment or higher rates to get all the way to the 60s.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hey, Jeff, this is Bill. Let me take it really high level and then we can sort of go down any tributary you want to go down and this is the way I would like to think about it because it's sort of makes it easy and it doesn't make it sort of dependent upon
componenttext: Hey, Jeff, this is Bill. Let me take it really high level and then we can sort of go down any tributary you want to go down and this is the way I would like to think about it because it's sort of makes it easy and it doesn't make it sort of dependent upon a bunch of exogenous factors. If you normalize a number of facts. So let's assume sort of a flat revenue environment. Let's assume we actually don't get another penny's worth of revenue. If you normalize our net charge-offs/provision at some basis. So normalize it whatever you want to but call it 50 to 70 basis points, which is clearly higher than we have trended in the past. If you normalize for 45, mortgage repurchase and just some number in there, any number, but it would be appreciably smaller than where it is today then you normalize for the credit related expenses, so they've ran about $800 million sort of annualized little higher than now they're running closer to $700 million annualized we're starting to see that benefit. Now it used to be 200. I don't think we'll get to there's. So pick a number and just cut it in half as a thought process. And then put $300 million in PPG on top of that and to get to that point essentially a 60% efficiency ratio on a 1% plus ROE. So at a really high level, that's sort of what gives us confidence. Now it won't work out that way exactly and there'll be puts and takes and the timing will be different. One quarter will be up one quarter will be down. But if you think about that in sort of a goal, that's it. Now to the point of PPG, if some of those things don't materialize, if the credit expenses don't come down like that, or if the charge-offs don't normalize the way I've described or in fact revenues down for some reason unforeseen then the number on the savings will be higher. That's how I'd like to think about it at really high level. Does that make sense?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Mueller, FDR.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Mueller, FDR.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: On Slide 7, of the mortgage repurchase trends I love this detail by the way, guys, best detail out there. There was a particular company yesterday one of your competitors said that they've sold their repurchase claims increased by the end of their from di
componenttext: On Slide 7, of the mortgage repurchase trends I love this detail by the way, guys, best detail out there. There was a particular company yesterday one of your competitors said that they've sold their repurchase claims increased by the end of their from discussions with the GSCs that they were going to get requests from every loan that have defaulted that they sold to them over the '05 '09 time period. I know you took a big charge back in the fourth quarter. Was that due to the same type of discussions? Are you getting all your files requested from the GSCs? I'm just wondering a lot of guys are guiding us to higher numbers towards end of the year and you're guiding to lower. So have you been already through that process for the GSCs?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I'm not sure where others are in their progress with the GSCs. But we feel like last year was our peak and probably the fourth quarter of last year was our peak in terms of total demand and provisions. As we look to the next several quarters, the trend
componenttext: So I'm not sure where others are in their progress with the GSCs. But we feel like last year was our peak and probably the fourth quarter of last year was our peak in terms of total demand and provisions. As we look to the next several quarters, the trends that we're seeing are for example, changes in full file requests and the nature of the full file requests which we are seeing now. And as you know, those are precursor to where future demands are moving toward loans that are earlier stage in delinquency and not in foreclosure. And given those trends, it looks to us like demands will decline over time. Now there's always going to be some volatility you will never know one quarter to another. But directionally, it does look like that given where we're seeing full file request demands will actually decline.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: So you've been getting full file requests since last year?
componenttext: So you've been getting full file requests since last year?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Oh, yes. We've been getting full file requests all the way through. The nature of those full file requests as they move away from foreclosed loans and towards delinquent loans is a key indicator for what we're expecting to see in future demands. I think w
componenttext: Oh, yes. We've been getting full file requests all the way through. The nature of those full file requests as they move away from foreclosed loans and towards delinquent loans is a key indicator for what we're expecting to see in future demands. I think we're improving our dialogue with the agencies all the time and as we continue to improve communication and dialogue and continue to gain confidence and what we expect to see we're starting to feel a little bit better about these numbers.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next question is from Matt O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm sure you've seen other banks try to take some front hit the reserve I'm just wondering one, do you just not have enough information to do this or do you not really believe in kind of kitchen sinking the quarter or how should we think about it? because
componenttext: I'm sure you've seen other banks try to take some front hit the reserve I'm just wondering one, do you just not have enough information to do this or do you not really believe in kind of kitchen sinking the quarter or how should we think about it? because we've seen others think that estimate what the lifetime losses would be at this point?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: We've just seen our CFO perspire a little bit. Thanks for the question Matt I think we're seeing a couple of things that have provided a lifetime loss but most happen. Most things, including us have got a reserve which reflect losses that are both probabl
componenttext: We've just seen our CFO perspire a little bit. Thanks for the question Matt I think we're seeing a couple of things that have provided a lifetime loss but most happen. Most things, including us have got a reserve which reflect losses that are both probable and estimable. And that line around probable and estimable losses in the reserve as the industry learns more from the GSCs probably converges with the line of an estimated lifetime loss. You might have a couple of banks this quarter that feel confident in their communication and what they're seeing and there've actually seen those 2 lines cross. I think from the whole industry, that is not the case yet probably over time as more and more communication improves with the GSCs, you will see those lines continue to converge and then cross.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I know it's difficult to know sitting here right now, but would you hope by the end of the year to have visibility that you can push this issue behind you 2013 and beyond or is your best guess that won't happen?
componenttext: I know it's difficult to know sitting here right now, but would you hope by the end of the year to have visibility that you can push this issue behind you 2013 and beyond or is your best guess that won't happen?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure exactly when it will happen, but if your question do I hope it will happen? Yes, I hope it will but I don't know that I can say we have complete confidence it will be by the end of this year. Obviously, the sooner the better.
componenttext: I'm not sure exactly when it will happen, but if your question do I hope it will happen? Yes, I hope it will but I don't know that I can say we have complete confidence it will be by the end of this year. Obviously, the sooner the better.

componenttext: Okay. And your comments about actual cost itself coming down kind of towards the end of year by the end of the year I guess it would imply cost in 3Q similar to 2Q and then hopefully down the fourth quarter?

componenttextpreview: I don't know I can give you an exact quarter but I can say yes, by the end of this year they will be down.
componenttext: I don't know I can give you an exact quarter but I can say yes, by the end of this year they will be down.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ed Najarian ISI Group.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ed Najarian ISI Group.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I guess my first question is a follow-up on Kris's question on operating costs. When I sort of look at your year-over-year op cost and normalize for the redemption cost this quarter but then I think you had $21 million of lower FDIC-related costs on a
componenttext: So I guess my first question is a follow-up on Kris's question on operating costs. When I sort of look at your year-over-year op cost and normalize for the redemption cost this quarter but then I think you had $21 million of lower FDIC-related costs on a year-over-year basis this quarter versus last quarter. And then again I tried to factor in the $250 million of PPG savings. It looks like your internal expense growth rate is running about 5% to 6% annually. Probably that is a little bit higher than what you would call sort of a more normalized growth rate x the PPG savings because of the revenue you talked about and because of the strong mortgage quarter. But could you give us a sense of what you think the sort of normal internal growth rate is x expense savings going forward. Would it be 3%, 4%, 5%? How should we think about that?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think the 5% number that you reference is generally about right. However, remember that includes the effect of the increased revenue growth also. Looking just at the expense line alone without looking at the revenue growth and the effect the positive ef
componenttext: I think the 5% number that you reference is generally about right. However, remember that includes the effect of the increased revenue growth also. Looking just at the expense line alone without looking at the revenue growth and the effect the positive effect that it's had on the bottom line might be a little bit one-sided. In terms of what we expect to see as a normalized expense growth number going forward, what we're shooting for is low single digits. And so certainly lower than 5% is what we would expect our core expense growth to be on a normalized basis.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then as a quick follow-up when I'm looking at the average balance sheet and I'm looking at your funding costs, specifically sort of aggregated interest-bearing funding cost, in the first quarter they were 77 basis points. They fell 1 basis point to 76
componenttext: And then as a quick follow-up when I'm looking at the average balance sheet and I'm looking at your funding costs, specifically sort of aggregated interest-bearing funding cost, in the first quarter they were 77 basis points. They fell 1 basis point to 76 basis points this quarter. So pretty flat. Now I recognize that you're going to get some benefit from reducing the TruPS in the third quarter. But other than that TruPS redemption benefit, do you feel like you're starting to run out of the room to further drop your funding cost. That's what would it looked like on sort of a one quarter look basis or do you feel like that there are some areas again excluding that TruPS benefit to continue to drive down funding costs.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I'm glad that you referenced as a one quarter look. And you're right, we only dropped 1 basis point this quarter. I don't think that's actually the start of flattening trend. Now having said that, deposit rates are absolute low level so it's hard for
componenttext: And I'm glad that you referenced as a one quarter look. And you're right, we only dropped 1 basis point this quarter. I don't think that's actually the start of flattening trend. Now having said that, deposit rates are absolute low level so it's hard for us or anybody to grind them down by double digits from here. But we do believe we still have some runway to drop deposit costs further from here and you may see some of that this quarter. One of the levers we have is maturing CDs. And we've got several billion dollars, $4 billion of CDs that are going to be maturing between now and the end of the year and they have the weighted average cost of north of 1%. And so you would expect to see those renew at much lower yields between now and at the end of the year and that will drop our deposit costs, I think much more than the 1 basis point you saw in Q2.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012

componenttext: Our next question is from Gerard Cassidy, RBC.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And then second on the cost savings program that you guys announced, one of your competitors yesterday, KeyCorp announced the cost-saving programs which is the second one for them, they had one in place at the end of 2011. What kind of environ
componenttext: Okay, good. And then second on the cost savings program that you guys announced, one of your competitors yesterday, KeyCorp announced the cost-saving programs which is the second one for them, they had one in place at the end of 2011. What kind of environment would you have to see where you would announce another similar type of program as the one that's in place now?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think sort of this goes back to my earlier comments this isn't so much about a program as it is a culture and it is about driving to a goal. So I'll continue to talk about what we're doing to drive to a 60% efficiency ratio. And in fairness, I'll p
componenttext: Yes, I think sort of this goes back to my earlier comments this isn't so much about a program as it is a culture and it is about driving to a goal. So I'll continue to talk about what we're doing to drive to a 60% efficiency ratio. And in fairness, I'll probably talk less about programs. As I mentioned in my comments, the program was really the catalyst. I mean that was to sort to set the initial bar, the starting gun to turn things around. So for us, it's really driving for a better efficiency ratio. Every unit in our company has an efficiency ratio target. They know what they're driving towards. There are lots of corporate initiatives underway that help them get there but there are a lot of good individuals smart thinking and smart management and it's going to be more about them than the announcement of another program.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012

componenttext: I'll move away from the expenses. Bill, in the Atlanta Journal last weekend you said SunTrust is the Goldilocks today or just the right size. I guess my question is are there certain markets where you need to have a greater presence to get to that Goldilocks position. And in light of the cost-cutting efforts, does it make sense to exit certain markets versus building a scale in investing?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks for reminding me of that reference. My point was right, I might have used a different reference. We have been very careful and plan full of having scale and relevance and I think relevance was the most important in all of our markets. There isn't a
componenttext:
Thanks for reminding me of that reference. My point was right, I might have used a different reference. We have been very careful and plan full of having scale and relevance and I think relevance was the most important in all of our markets. There isn't a particular market today that I would say we're not relevant in that we're looking to have an exit in. Everywhere that we are, we've got an opportunity and we are a big enough either with branches or commercial lenders or CIB or mortgage or some combination of businesses that we're engaged in, in a market to be relevant. Now that being said, are we constantly looking at everything and looking at efficiencies and do we have an opportunity intra-market with leveraging our in stores and traditional branches and loan production ops and all that, sure we'll always be looking at that. But a great part of our franchise is the fact that we are in great markets and we are relevant in those markets. So as a general piece, no. 
Okay. Great. Maybe just a quick comment before we wrap up the call. And thank you. And though we cannot change the operating environment or the pace of which before recovery happens, but there is play that we can do and have been doing and continue to do here at SunTrust. We're building a more effective and efficient company. We're improving our talent base by ensuring that our teammates have the tools and training they need to uncover and meet more client needs to deliver the revenue results that we expect. A simple way of putting it is we are building more intensity around everything we do and virtually every corner of our organization. So with that being said, again, thank you for joining us today and please reach out to Investor Relations and Kris with any additional questions that you may have.
