componenttext: Welcome to the SunTrust Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I would now like to introduce Kris Dickson, Director of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lindy, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to SunTrust Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call, and thank you for joining us. In addition to the present, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we are planning to address during ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Lindy, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to SunTrust Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call, and thank you for joining us. In addition to the present, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we are planning to address during our call today. The presentation and detailed financials are available on our website, www.suntrust.com. This information can be accessed by going to the Investor Relations section of the website. With me today, among other members of our executive management team are Bill Rogers, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Aleem Gillani, our Chief Financial Officer and Tom Freeman, our Chief Risk Officer. 
Before we get started, I need to remind you that our comments today may include forward-looking statements the agree statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially. We list the factors that might cause actual results to differ materially in our press release and SEC filings, which are available in our website. 
During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures in talking about the company's performance. You can find the reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measure in our press release and on our website, www.suntrust.com. 
Finally, SunTrust is not responsible for and does not edit nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings call transcripts provided by third parties. The only authorized live and archived webcasts are located on our website. With that, I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Kris. In our normal fashion, I will begin today's call with a brief overview of the quarter. After passing it to Aleem, I'll wrap up with an update on our expense saving program and provide some recent business highlights. First, I will be
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Kris. In our normal fashion, I will begin today's call with a brief overview of the quarter. After passing it to Aleem, I'll wrap up with an update on our expense saving program and provide some recent business highlights. 
First, I will begin by acknowledging there are a lot of moving parts this quarter. We have endeavored in our remarks today and throughout the presentation of I do clarity on those items and how it impacted the results. Aleem will provide more detail momentarily and I think you'll see that we continue the trend of delivering improved quarter performance. Further, we're positioned more favorably coming out of the quarter in large part due to the actions we announced in September. Our overall risk profiles improved and our balance sheet has strengthened. This is highlighted by lower nonperforming and delinquent loans and a mortgage repurchase reserve that now fully covers estimated remaining losses on the pre-2009 vintage GSE loans. As you know, those are loans from which a vast majority of the mass of losses have been generated, and we are able to accomplish this while continuing to grow our capital base this quarter. 
Now turning to the presentation. Slide 3 summarizes some of the key drivers of our third quarter results. Earnings per share was $1.98 with the actions we announced last month contributing $1.40 per share. The diversity of our revenue streams benefited us this quarter. Mortgage production was again strong and investment banking income also increased, while net interest income and margin were relatively stable to the prior quarter. Expenses were up on a reported basis but excluding the noncore items, they were stable the last quarter and down from the prior year. As you are aware, this continues to be an area where we have lots of focus as we strive to achieve our ultimate goal of a sub-60 efficiency ratio. I'm going to talk about this in the context of our PPG program later in the call. 
Now take a look at the balance sheet. Overall loan growth was slow but growth in targeted categories, particularly C&I, drove a nearly $1 billion increase in average performing loan balances over last quarter and a nearly $10 billion increase over last year. This more than offset certain real estate related loans that we have been actively managing down. Now on the deposit side, the favorable mix continued with average DDA growth of 3% from the prior quarter and 19% from the prior year. From a credit perspective, the de-risking of the balance sheet helped drive a 30% reduction in nonperforming loans over last quarter and a 47% decline from last year. And as I mentioned earlier, our capital position continue to increase with our Tier 1 common equity ratio estimated at 9.8%, up 40 basis points last quarter. 
All in all, we're continuing to demonstrate improved quarter performance. And that, coupled with proactive actions we took this quarter, positions us well for the future. I'm going to turn it over to Aleem and let him walk you through the details and give you more clarity on the quarters results. Aleem?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us today. After several noise-free quarters and consistently improving results, as Bill noted, we had a number of lumpy items that impacted the third quarter. So I'll spend a few minutes groundi
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us today. After several noise-free quarters and consistently improving results, as Bill noted, we had a number of lumpy items that impacted the third quarter. So I'll spend a few minutes grounding you on them before we get to the operating results. Please turn to Slide 4. I'll start with an update on the items we preannounced in September. The acceleration of the agreement regarding our Coca-Cola shares generated $1.9 billion in securities gains. And the charitable contribution of 1 million coke shares to the SunTrust Foundation resulted in the recognition of $38 million. Our third quarter mortgage repurchase provision was $371 million. Consistent with last month's announcement and as Bill noted earlier, we expect mortgage repurchase reserve to cover the estimated remaining losses from pre-2009 vintage loans sold to the GSE. During the third quarter, we transferred to held-for-sale slightly $500 million of nonperforming mortgage and Commercial Real Estate loans. The total net charge of recognized in the writing the loans not in disposition value was $172 million. The majority of the loan sales were completed during the third quarter with only about $40 million in net balances remaining to be sold this quarter. We also transferred to held-for-sale $1.4 billion of student loans and $500 million of delinquent Ginnie Mae loans. In doing so, we wrote these loans down to the expected sales price and the $92 million charge, most of which was associated with the delinquent Ginnie Mae loans, was a reduction to noninterest income. You will recall, the majority of the combined $1.9 billion in student and Ginnie Mae loans we're selling are more than 90 days delinquent. Their disposition reduces our delinquency ratio and makes the size of our government guaranteed loan volume more consistent with our longer-term balance sheet target. All of the transferred loans were included in loans held-for-sale at the quarter end. The date in the fourth quarter, we have already sold $1 billion of student loans and we expect complete the remaining student and Ginnie Mae sales by year end. 
We also transferred approximately $190 million of affordable housing investments to held-for-sale during the quarter. The $96 million write-down taken upon the transfer was recorded as a noninterest expense, and the resulted carrying value reflects our best estimate of the ultimate disposition price. We expect this sale will be completed in the second quarter of 2013. Combined, the preannounced items contributed $753 million in net income or $1.40 per common share to the third quarter results. This was exactly on our prior guidance. 
Shifting to the bottom portion of Slide 4, you see 4 other items. The first of which relates to credit policy change. During the third quarter, we moved the timing of charge-off recognition for junior lien loans from 180 days to 120 days. Our analysis indicated that when junior liens go 120 days past due, they rarely cure and typically roll to 180 days. Accordingly, we altered our policy, which resulted in the accelerated recognition of $65 million in incremental net charge-offs in the quarter. For clarity, this is not related to the policy change other large banks made this quarter regarding the treatment of consumer loan that were not reaffirmed following Chapter 7 bankruptcy. We have not received to 2 guidance from our regulator and have not taken any action in response. However, we are monitoring development. We do estimate that we have approximately $400 million of such loans, about 35% of which are already classified as performing TDRs. We expect to receive coordinated regulatory guidance on this issue and will take any appropriate action at that time. I'll cover the final 3 items on the page fairly quickly. I'm pleased to note that our credit spreads tightened considerably in the third quarter. Unfortunately, this also resulted in $41 million in mark-to-market losses on our fair value, which reduced noninterest income. Next, we accrued $29 million in severance expense associated with post-PPG efforts to streamline our organization and achieve our efficiency ratio objectives. And lastly, we incurred a $17 million expense associated with reassessments and ultimate reduction of our real estate need. 
Slide 5 provides a summary income statement and the collective impact of the items that I just reviewed. Third quarter noninterest income was up substantial from prior quarters and the gain from the Coca-Cola transaction more than offset the increased mortgage repurchase provision, the write-down on the student and Ginnie Mae loan sales and the mark-to-market loss on the fair value adjustment. Provision for credit losses increased this quarter due to the NPL sales and the credit policy change. Expenses were higher due to the affordable housing write-down, the coke shares donation, severance and the real estate charges. 
Looking at the bottom line, third quarter 2012 earnings per share of $1.98 was up markedly compared to the prior quarters. Obviously, a lot of the favorable variance is driven by the $1.40 per share impact of the September actions. After backing that out, this quarter's EPS of $0.58 continued our favorable core earnings, and it compares favorably to the $0.39 from a year ago and the $0.50 from last quarter. 
Subsequent slides provide clear reviews of our underlying trend. So let's turn to Slide 6 for a discussion of net interest income, which was $1.3 billion this quarter and the margin was 3.38%, both of which were down slightly from the prior quarter. Interest income from assets declined about $50 million sequentially. This was driven by 3 primary factors. First, we experienced 10 basis points of loan yield compression, mainly driven by mortgage and C&I as new loans that were originating are coming on the books at lower yields than those that are paying off. Second, we saw a 38 basis point decline in our securities yield, which was largely attributable to the elimination of the $15 million quarterly Coke dividend. And lastly, we continue to modestly reduce the size of our bond portfolio in light of the lack of attractive investment alternative. 
On the liability side, interest expense declined sequentially by $44 million, and the cost of interest-bearing liabilities was managed down by 14 basis points. This was driven by the reduced funding needs associated with the smaller balance sheet, the previously announced redemption of $1.2 billion of higher cost trust preferred securities earlier in the quarter and the maturity of a population of higher cost CD, which helped drive the overall time deposit down about 20 basis points. Relative to the prior year, net interest income was up modestly and the margin declined 10 basis points. Key drivers were lower earning asset yields, higher loan balances and reduced interest cost associated with an improved deposit mix, lower deposit rates paid and the reduction in long-term debt. 
As we look to the fourth quarter, we expect to see a reduction in the net interest margin on the order of mid-single digit basis points, driven by additional reductions in asset yields, which will partially be offset by lower yet liability costs. In the fourth quarter, we expect the reduction to net interest income as a result of the lower margin, coupled with our smaller balance sheet due to the closed and pending loan sales. 
Let's turn to Slide 7 for a discussion of noninterest income. As we discussed earlier, reported noninterest income was up substantially this quarter due to the favorable net impact associated with the September assets actions. As usual, we've also provided a view of our adjusted noninterest income and we detailed the adjustments in the appendix. The $216 million sequential quarter increase in the mortgage repurchase provision, which is booked as a contra revenue drove the decline in adjusted noninterest income in the second quarter. Otherwise, fee income trends this quarter were solid. Most notable was core mortgage production. Excluding the impact of the repurchase provision, mortgage production income hit a record high this quarter and increased $49 million or almost 20% sequentially. Production volume was high and stable to the second quarter level of about $8 billion, which was split roughly 70-30 between refinancing and repurchasing. 
Looking ahead, while it is reasonable to assume some volume and margin compression, we do expect overall conditions in the mortgage market to continue to remain favorable in the near term. 
Investment banking was another business that was up sequentially, driven by strong syndication volume. Conversely, the other charges and fee category declined as a result of lower commitment fees and card fees fell due to a reclassification of card award process. Relative to the prior year, adjusted noninterest income declined $111 million, driven by a $254 million increase in the mortgage repurchase provision. Apart from this, adjusted noninterest income increased $143 million or 15%. Similar to the sequential quarter comparisons, strong core mortgage production was the primary driver and higher investment banking revenue also contributed, driven by syndication and bond origination fee. Conversely, card fees declined primarily due to the impact of regulatory reform. 
Let's turn to Slide 8 to take a look at mortgage repurchases. For consistency's sake, we've continued to share with you the same layout of this page from prior quarters. But obviously the important news on mortgage repurchase issue for us this quarter was contained within our September announcement. Specifically, as a result of additional information we received from both Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, coupled with our own analysis of the patterns of demand and file request, we were able to more precisely estimate the remaining losses on pre-2009 GSE loans, the population of loans that today have accounted for about 95% of all repurchase losses. As such, we recorded a $371 million provision this quarter, and the resulting mortgage reserve, which you can see on the bottom left of this page increased to $694 million. Looking forward, we expect this reserve level to decline as the losses are recognized. 
The top left portion of this slide shows that demand declined $405 million this quarter, driven primarily by the 2006 to '08 vintages. Demand levels could continue to very in the coming quarters. However, the trends and the full requests precursors the future demand are improving in 2 ways. First, the absolute number to full file requests are declining. This suggests that, over time, we should begin seeing a decline in the over level of demand. Second, the percentage of full file requests for loans that have never been 120 days past due is increasing, and more recently delinquent loans tend to have better cure rates. The pending demand population, which is displayed on the top right portion of this page increased to $690 million. This is due to the new demand and a modest extension of resolution timing. We continue to take a deliberate approach in reviewing repurchase demand, ensuring that we purchase loans where appropriate yet cure the defects or moderate losses wherever possible. Overall and in line with what we said in September, the mortgage repurchase trends continue to play out in a manner consistent with our expectations and information we received from the agencies. 
Let's move on to expenses. Adjusted expenses were essentially stable to the prior quarter. Other real estate cost declined $22 million due to lower losses on disposition, and outside processing fell $9 million. These were offset by increases in employee compensation and FDIC premiums. The $18 million compensation increase was largely due to the accelerated vesting of deferred compensation associated with certain organizational changes and to a lesser degree higher contract labor cost. $7 million increase in our FDIC premium is due to quarterly variability in the assessment. Relative to the prior year, adjusted expenses declined $24 million or 2%, credit-related cost of decline driven by a combined $38 million reduction in other real estate and collection services expenses. FDIC premiums also fell by $13 million. Partially offsetting these reductions was an employee compensation and benefits increase of $30 million. This was in part due to the aforementioned accelerated vesting of certain deferred compensation, as well as an overall improvement in business performance. 
As we look to the fourth quarter, we currently expect our adjusted expenses to be flat to down. Higher costs are expected to continue their overall declining trend and employee compensation is expected to decline. Conversely, certain volume and seasonally driven buying items for example, outside processing and advertising may increase. 
Let's turn to the balance sheet on Slide 10. Average performing loans increased by about $900 million or 1%. Growth was driven again this quarter by C&I, which was up $1.1 billion or 2% and came predominantly from large corporate clients with not-for-profit and auto dealer also contributing. and C&I growth was less robust than recent quarters as we saw some slowing in loan demand due to borrowers uncertainty associated with the economic environment and the fiscal cliff. That said, loan pipelines still remain fairly strong. I'll also point out that our corporate investment banking it has benefited in the increased activity on the bond market by improving bond origination fees during the last couple of quarters. Relative to the prior year performing loans increased by $9.5 billion or 8%. C&I was the largest driver up $5.7 billion or 12% with growth across a diverse array of industry verticals. Additionally, the student loans were up by $2.4 billion and guaranteed mortgages, nonguaranteed mortgages and indirect consumer all increased by around $1 billion. The overall portfolio growth was partially offset by intentional decline in home equity, commercial real estate and construction. The effects of this de-risking is shown on Slide 11. The portfolio that we've categorized as higher risk declined by another $0.5 billion this quarter. While we've continue to apply the high-risk label to this grouping of loans, I'd point out that 95% of this book is accruing. And of that, 90% is current on principal and on interest. The nonaccruing high-risk loans has been appropriate reserves for us and the accruing book looks a lot like the rest of our portfolio. For example, the weighted average referenced FICO scores of the high-risk mortgage and equity books are well above 700. Due to the improved performance of the higher risk about and its smaller absolute size, you ask can expect less above this portfolio in future quarters. You see in the bottom part of this page that the government guaranteed portfolio declined by $2.3 billion this quarter. This is largely due to the transfers to held-for-sale of $1.4 billion of student loans and $0.5 billion of Ginnie Mae loans. In the fourth quarter, we also expect a transfer to held-for-sale another approximately $600 million of student loans. This $600 million was included in the loan sales guidance that we gave in September, but did not meet the held-for-sale accounting criteria at quarter end. We do not expect the gain or loss associated with the fourth quarter transfer to be material. 
Let's take a look at Slide 12 for a review of credit trends. Overall, the credit story is again an improving one this quarter. Early stage delinquency ratios were relatively stable to the prior quarter. Consumer loan saw a normal seasonal increases, which were partially offset by declines in home equity delinquencies. Excluding government guaranteed loans, consumer and delinquency ratios were 58 and 18 basis points, respectively, which are at relatively low levels. As such and as is the case with most of our credit metrics, we would expect residential loans to draw in future improvements as residential delinquencies are still somewhat elevated by historical standards at just about 1%. Nonperforming assets and nonperforming loans were down by over $700 million from the prior quarter. A 30% sequential quarter decline in nonperforming loans was largely due to the $544 million sale of the mortgage and CRE NPLs. However, excluding these sales, NPL still declined by about $185 million or over 70%. This decline came despite our adding to NPL. For regulatory guidance, $81 million in junior lien loans are current on their payments but subordinate to delinquent mortgage. At quarter end, our ratio of nonperforming loans to total loans was 1.42%, down from 1.97% last quarter and 2.67% a year ago. This brought our allowance to NPL ratio up to 130%, a rise of 36 percentage points from the second quarter. 
Net charge-offs this quarter were $511 million as compared to $350 million last quarter. Included in this quarter's figure is the $172 million in net charge-offs associated with NPL sales and the $65 million from the junior lien credit policy change. Backing these 2 figures out, net charge-offs were $274 million, down $76 million sequentially. Four net charge-offs have printed favorably for some time, and we expect that overall trend to continue in the coming quarters. We could see some increase in the fourth quarter from this $274 million level though as a function of some normal seasonality and the fact that our recoveries were about $30 million higher this quarter than what we've experienced recently. The allowance for loan and lease losses end of the quarter at $2.2 billion, down about $60 million from the prior quarter due to the improving core credit quality trends. Despite the modest dollar decline and the allowance of this quarter, the allowance ratio remains essentially unchanged at 1.84% on a stated basis or just about 2% when excluding government guaranteed loans from the calculation. 
Taking a step back, when you take a look at what we have done to improve the risk profile of the organization over the last while, the last 2 slides make that real evident. We have been aggressively and intentionally reducing our high-risk book for several years. Those balances are down by $14.6 billion or more than 60% over the past few years. So our de-risking is largely complete. Nonperforming loans have been on a similar trajectory, down by $3.8 billion or almost 70% since their peak in 2009. And we took actions to further accelerate this decline this quarter as well as reduce our 90-day plus delinquency ratio. Overall, we have made meaningful and substantial strides that have resulted in a much improved risk profile for SunTrust. 
Let's next take a look at our deposit loan. Average deposit balances declined modestly from the prior quarter, and the favorable shift in deposit mix continues. Non-interest-bearing deposits were up $1.3 billion or 3%. This was essentially offset by $1.2 billion or 7% reduction in time deposits as we had an above average amount of DDA maturities during the third quarter. We also saw a modest decline in money market balances as we're being deliberate about pricing discipline and have let certain promotional rates expire. Relative to the prior year, deposits were up $2.4 billion or about 2%. Lower-cost accounts are in the driver of the growth, led by almost $6 billion or 19% DDA growth. Conversely, higher cost time deposits are down by $3.4 billion or 17%. 
Slide 14 provides information on our capital metrics. Tier 1 common capital increased by approximately $400 million. Recall that the September actions were essentially neutral to our regulatory capital level, so this quarter's increase is primarily driven by core earnings. The Tier 1 common ratio ended the quarter at an estimated 9.8%, up a healthy 40 basis points from last quarter. Our estimate for the Basel III Tier 1 common ratio, assuming that all the components of the Federal Reserve's recent notice of proposed rulemaking in their current form held relatively stable at 7.9%. 
As shown at the bottom of the page, the tangible common equity ratio increased by 16 basis points sequentially due to a reduction in the asset base, and tangible book value per share ended the quarter at $25.72, down 1% from the prior quarter as the modest tangible book value dilution associated with the September actions was largely offset by this quarter us core earning. 
With that, I will now turn things back over to Bill to cover the last few slides.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'll move to Slide 15. And during the third quarter, we achieved our PPG expense program target well ahead of schedule, realizing a little over $75 million in quarterly savings or obviously $300 million on an annualized run rate. The collective
componenttext:
Okay. And I'll move to Slide 15. And during the third quarter, we achieved our PPG expense program target well ahead of schedule, realizing a little over $75 million in quarterly savings or obviously $300 million on an annualized run rate. The collective effort that got us here so quickly should not be minimized. A lot was accomplished in a relatively short period of time, and that's a result of our teammates intensity around delivering results. With that being said, it's not loss on me or anyone at SunTrust that we still have work to do. The PPG program served as a catalyst towards achieving our ultimate goal of the significantly improving the overall organization. It's been successful and not only garnering meaningful savings, but also in galvanizing our team in pursuit of our sub-60 efficiency ratio goal. 
So now that we've hit our PPG target, what kind of updates can we expect. Well, we're not going to roll out a new program with a new name nor do we publicly track our progress beyond the $300 million goal. But I will tell you that we're not finished in our efforts to improve our efficiency. As a matter fact, we're just getting started. And going forward, I want you to measure us by the same metric that we're holding ourselves accountable, our efficiency ratio. We have incorporated this metric into our incentive compensation plan. We have built a lot of intensity throughout the bank improving revenue and expense components of the calculation. So PPG was instrumental in getting us on the track, and we'll leverage that momentum as we go forward. 
Moving to the next slide and before we move into Q&A, I want to spend a few minutes highlighting the progress we've made from a business perspective. And consumer banking and private wealth management, we spent another quarter of solid loan production growth in the year-to-date volume 15% ahead of last year. Favorable deposit trends also continued as we generated year-over-year DDA growth of 14%. And though from a revenue perspective, this business continues to be challenged due to regulatory headwinds, we have reduced expenses here by about 3% last year. Clients are increasingly utilizing self-service channels, which is just one example that enabled us to make changes to our staffing model to improve our efficiency and effectiveness. Our wholesale business continues to deliver strong results with year-to-date net income nearly double what it was a year ago. Significant growth in capital markets fee, coupled with a higher net interest income drove wholesale revenue gains of 14% over the third quarter of last year. Loans were up 8% and Client deposits increased 5%. Furthermore,, our corporate investment banking business surpassed last quarter's revenue and net income levels marking yet another quarter of record performance. While the mortgage business reported a net loss, primarily due to the increase in mortgage repurchase reserve and the mortgage NPL sale, core trends continue to markedly improve. Year-to-date mortgage production volume was $24 billion, up nearly $8 billion or 48% from last year and core mortgage origination income was $460 million higher, more than 130% increase from last year. The elevated levels of refinance activity have certainly been beneficial to the business while we're also continued to develop resources to purchase activity, our core bread and butter business for us that we think will again be the primary driver of mortgage revenue when the refi volume eventually takes result. Additionally, we also focus on building a catalyst in driving while them with better channel selection to maximize ROI in the longer-term return profile for this business. So overall, this marked another quarter of positively trending core line of business performance. The diversity of our business mix has and will continue to benefit us as we go forward and I'm pleased with the high intensity level that which our team leaders and teammates are operating, focused on meeting our clients need and driving higher levels return of our shareholders. Kris, let me turn it back over to you and we'll take some questions.

componenttextpreview: Sure. As you know the big issue obviously is that the new loans coming are on coming on lower on yields than the roll-off, and securities continue to pay down. We're being very careful with the way in which we reinvest our securities book. Obviously, we'r
componenttext: Sure. As you know the big issue obviously is that the new loans coming are on coming on lower on yields than the roll-off, and securities continue to pay down. We're being very careful with the way in which we reinvest our securities book. Obviously, we're not really getting paid given the flat yield curve that take a lot of duration risk. And you saw that impact a little bit in the size of our figurative upcoming gun this quarter. But I think what you'll see with the whole industry as you look out therefore, if we stay in this longer environment next year I think you'll see the whole industry started decreet margins probably a few basis points per quarter every quarter just continuing to grind down.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012

componenttextpreview: It may accelerated rate or decelerate, too. I don't know that it is are consistent every quarter decline. There is some variability quarter-to-quarter, and this quarter we did receive the benefit of a number of our higher-cost CD rolling off. And that's w
componenttext: It may accelerated rate or decelerate, too. I don't know that it is are consistent every quarter decline. There is some variability quarter-to-quarter, and this quarter we did receive the benefit of a number of our higher-cost CD rolling off. And that's why our margin declined only 1 basis point overall. So I think look for some volatility with some quarters declining less and some quarters declining in more. But if you look at a trend overall, I'd look it for them to really be on the order of a few basis points this quarter.

And from there if you would assess the driver reaching the targeted levels need see more revenue side to expense side from here to get there?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: So let's start with I think you've got it figured out. Obviously, this quarter's efficiency ratio is a little lower. We were very clear internally that it wasn't mission accomplished. If you think about our core expense base say over the last 6 quarters,
componenttext: So let's start with I think you've got it figured out. Obviously, this quarter's efficiency ratio is a little lower. We were very clear internally that it wasn't mission accomplished. If you think about our core expense base say over the last 6 quarters, it has been fairly stable $1.5 billion so the core expense base but the revenue sort of has gone from $2.2 billion to $2.4 billion. So you could say one side of the coin we expect to see more expense savings at this particular juncture. But we're had a couple of our by this mortgages and mortgage and CIB has been 2 of those examples, we're going to invest in right now because we see good revenue opportunities. So think about it some sort of context what's left, what are the opportunities. And in a pretty significant. We have a lot more to do in the consumer rationalization of our business, expands in layers, incentive efficiencies. You saw some of the charges we took for real estate, so we still have some other real estate opportunities. Core process, consolidation, shared services. I mean the list is actually fairly extensive. And while I said PPG was a start I meant that. It really sort of the ball rolling down the hill. I would tell may be some of them are low-lying fruit now we're going to to get a little higher in the tree but there are significant opportunities. Is it more expense or is it more revenue a lot of that will depend on the the market takes us. If refinance activity continues like we think it will in mortgage, it will be a little slower to get the down with that efficiency ratio. We continue to do what we've been able to do on the CIB. Similarly, it will take a little bit longer. Similarly I think I've been very clear saying that efficiency ratio versus just expense or just revenue initiatives. And I'm confident that we're on the path. I can't commit to the exact time line but I'm confident that we're on the path. If you look into our line of businesses, start looking of efficiency improvements within both and I think they're pretty good leading indicator of where we're going as a total company.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I can just ask one follow-up as a follow-up to John's question. When you think about you obviously said the NIM coming down a couple of basis points when you think about the trajectory for NII for 4Q and beyond how should we think about just lean
componenttext: Okay. If I can just ask one follow-up as a follow-up to John's question. When you think about you obviously said the NIM coming down a couple of basis points when you think about the trajectory for NII for 4Q and beyond how should we think about just lean comments on asset yield spreads and reinvestment yields should we expect that NII is going to come down at a similar space or do you think you can actually see enough growth to offset the compression.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think next year, Ryan, I would think NII for the full year likely to be lower than the full year 2012. Basically we've got the changes from the foregone dividend and Coca-Cola end and the loans sales. In Q2 recall we had a step down on loan swap i
componenttext: Well, I think next year, Ryan, I would think NII for the full year likely to be lower than the full year 2012. Basically we've got the changes from the foregone dividend and Coca-Cola end and the loans sales. In Q2 recall we had a step down on loan swap income. So full year, I would think being lower than next year than this year. There's some positives and negatives in there. On the positive side, with continuing to manage down our non-deposit maturity rates. Obviously, in the compressed yield environment on liabilities, there's a decreasing opportunity there but we do have more CDs maturing $7 million CDs maturing the next 5 quarters between now and the end of next year. And as those renew, they will renew at lower yields. And against that, we're fighting against the challenging asset yield compressed environment. And as a reminder, we will have another step down as a result of swap rolling off in Q2 next year. So year-over-year, I would think of NII coming down overall, but we know still have some leverage to pull and we're working on those.

componenttext: We do expect those cost to continue to come down a bit Matt. I think maybe to be fair to the rest of the industry, we have been a little bit slower in coming down here. So I think this quarter, we're catching up a little bit. And you'll recall that, that in September we had guided some of those costs down by about $20 million per quarter for the end of the year. And we achieved a $15 million of that $20 million this quarter. So perhaps a little bit faster than we had anticipated but we do continue to expect those to continue to come down.

componenttext: That's generally correct. Obviously some volatility not able to forecast these costs within $5 million on a quarterly basis, but that's generally correct. We expected to hit by $20 million by year-end. We achieve a lot of that very quickly, but after we hit the $20 million, I would continue to expect those costs to move down next year.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012

componenttext: I want to ask you about the loan demand and was talking about the slowing loan demand and you were talking about the pipeline is strong. Can you talk about the kind of what you're seeing there to offer those comments altogether?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jefferson. Yes, and it is a bit of a dichotomy of different views but what we're seeing is some slowdown I think that has not been consistent with the search of NHA data. But our pipelines had actually very good and they are as large or not larger th
componenttext: Yes, Jefferson. Yes, and it is a bit of a dichotomy of different views but what we're seeing is some slowdown I think that has not been consistent with the search of NHA data. But our pipelines had actually very good and they are as large or not larger that they've been in prior quarters, the pull through rate is just slower. And we can all speculate as to why that might be. I think there clearly is some pent-up demand. When I'm out about and talking to other business owners and CEOs oh what I hear is we're going to wait. So we are encouraged by the fact that the pipeline is up. We're encouraged by the fact that we're having increased higher level dialogue with our clients, but the pull-through rate almost was lower this quarter. No doubt about it.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: So you think about that 2% average loan growth this quarter do you think that should generally pick up or slow down maybe the same in the future?
componenttext: So you think about that 2% average loan growth this quarter do you think that should generally pick up or slow down maybe the same in the future?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: It is hard to speculate because we are sort of dealing with a bit of a new phenomenon here. Normally, we can look at pipelines a good describable through rate of some consistency against those and be able to project that with a lot more consistency. Today
componenttext: It is hard to speculate because we are sort of dealing with a bit of a new phenomenon here. Normally, we can look at pipelines a good describable through rate of some consistency against those and be able to project that with a lot more consistency. Today there's a little bit more of an unknown. So while I'm optimistic overall in the sense that the pipelines are big and the activity and the dialogue, I'm a little hesitant to predict exactly what's going to happen in the next quarter or 2.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012

componenttext: Our next question is from Kenneth Usdin from Jefferies.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-on an environmental expense question real quick. So 2 of the most important lines operating losses credit and collection are slightly higher quarter-to-quarter and taking your point it's hard to think about quarter-to-quarter. I just wanted
componenttext: Just a follow-on an environmental expense question real quick. So 2 of the most important lines operating losses credit and collection are slightly higher quarter-to-quarter and taking your point it's hard to think about quarter-to-quarter. I just wanted to ask a more qualitative question. What does it take for those 2 lines to start I know you're expecting those 2 subcategories are going to improve, How long is the lag versus other credit improvement for operating losses and credit and collections specifically to really start moving down? Is there a trigger point where they just start to accelerate our is this a multiyear to reduce?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I certainly hope that's not a multiyear drag. I don't know that there is a trigger point that I could point you to but I think there are sort of several things you can look at improvement that we've made over the last couple of years particularly some of
componenttext: I certainly hope that's not a multiyear drag. I don't know that there is a trigger point that I could point you to but I think there are sort of several things you can look at improvement that we've made over the last couple of years particularly some of the actions that we took this quarter also, the sale of some of our NPL loans, the sale of the Ginnie Maes. That should help also reduce some of those credit and collection costs going forward. Those are very labor-intensive loan to attempt to collect and work on over time. And so I think of that as a little bit of a trigger point. And in operating losses, there are a lot of numbers built into there, built into that, that includes operational losses that includes broad losses that includes that we've got ended a buildup litigation reserves. So there's a lot of different numbers in there and I would look for that line did also start to come down relatively quickly as we start thinking about 2013 now. And in fairness this number other numbers as well. I've been pretty clear in stating that are going to be conservative and taking some of these cost down. I mean, this was a very expensive system to build. We're really, really good at it. And so some of these hard cost and tracking is down, we're going to probably lag little bit. And I think that's the prudent way to do it. We don't want the truck ahead of the gas line so to speak. So were going to be probably a little bit conservative in bringing this down. And think about it, a lot of the cost they just happened in the third quarter. So we'll start seeing some of that run rate comes through in the fourth quarter and moving forward.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess more of a conceptual question related to the mortgage business which is obviously doing very, very well right now. But one of the questions I often get from investors how confident you all are that you can take costs out of the mortgage once that
componenttext: I guess more of a conceptual question related to the mortgage business which is obviously doing very, very well right now. But one of the questions I often get from investors how confident you all are that you can take costs out of the mortgage once that was begins in normal highest at some point next year and how might that affect you thinking on the efficiency ratio.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take a shot. The expenses related to the mortgage business don't follow an exact quarter-to-quarter. As I said in my comments, not only sort of use what I call the traditional methods so you see that the client you see the normal expenses come d
componenttext: Yes, I'll take a shot. The expenses related to the mortgage business don't follow an exact quarter-to-quarter. As I said in my comments, not only sort of use what I call the traditional methods so you see that the client you see the normal expenses come down and they tend to lag a quarter or 2 depending on how much of a volume is purchased and how much is refinanced. So obviously lag more refinanced, less repurchase. But what we're doing this is a fairly significant sort of redesign of the channels in the business as we're going through this. One of the real silver linings behind the HARP is it really is opportunity to build out our consumer direct channel. And that channel as a percent of our business a year ago was pretty small. It's about 10% of our business now, and it is a much more efficient part of a structure. So not only did you have a traditional tools we're going through a redesigned of the channel mix I'm actually fairly confident that come out of this will come out of this with a higher-margin business relative to how we entered this from the changes we are making now. I would also add one more point I'd also remind you that over the last little while, we have spent several tens of million of dollars around sent order, consulting cost around the independent workload review. And as you look out to next year, I would expect all of those costs to abate, and that will also provide a nice lift to the overall performance of the mortgage loan.

componenttext: In total, our total origination, Matt, it was about sort of 70-30 refi versus purchase. And of the refi, about 30% of the total refi was HARP. Now if you work that through about 20% of our total business this quarter was HARP.

componenttext: I think, Gerard, if you take a look at the expense slide that we got 28 in the deck yes, you get the sense of what the environment cost would have been within that number. And as we said earlier that our run rate is coming down pretty nicely from where it was last year, and I would expect that to continue to come down. If you think about a really normalized number, I mean back in the day, that line item for us had a run rate of about $200 million annually. I don't think that we'll ever get back to that kind of a number, but it might be reasonable to assume that, that kind of a number from $200 million might double. But even when it doubles, it's half of the $800 million we ran last year.

componenttext: Great. And if you're required to put the entire $400 million on nonperforming, what type of provision you have to take to build that reserve?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I can give you an answer to that that guidance came out right at end of the quarter and we are not subject to it so we are currently doing the analysis to see what the total looks like. But at the high level, I think given that these are perf
componenttext: I'm not sure I can give you an answer to that that guidance came out right at end of the quarter and we are not subject to it so we are currently doing the analysis to see what the total looks like. But at the high level, I think given that these are performing loans, you would expect that the reserve against them would be very nominal minimal and nonexistent. And the idea that we would take them and put them into nonperforming may or may not have an impact on provisions. We're still waiting for coordinated guidance across from all the agencies. And obviously, when we hear that we will take action immediately.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Maybe a bigger quester picture. A question for you Bill, we've seen a number of housing data points to be very positive particularly in the Southeast in terms of home prices housing starts a pretty steady stream of good data. How does that im
componenttext: Okay, great. Maybe a bigger quester picture. A question for you Bill, we've seen a number of housing data points to be very positive particularly in the Southeast in terms of home prices housing starts a pretty steady stream of good data. How does that impact SunTrust from a bigger picture standpoint in terms of demand to maybe seeing Florida it had a tremendous backlog in Florida maybe seeing that speed up and does that ultimately help lower these credit If this trajectory continues the credit cost faster?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think actually the biggest tie to housing value increase and what it does for us is increasing consumer confidence. I honestly think that's sort of the biggest if you can think about sort of where people are coming from this being their largest asset. W
componenttext:
I think actually the biggest tie to housing value increase and what it does for us is increasing consumer confidence. I honestly think that's sort of the biggest if you can think about sort of where people are coming from this being their largest asset. When that starts to change, they look at total their -- as a general comment and more deleverage than they were before. I think this just cause unlock some of that consumer confidence. We are still more tied to employment than housing values, but that's also seeing some positive trajectory. I mean take for example. Well still above the national average the improvement in Florida and unemployment's gone from 9.6 to 8.7. So the largest probably percent of improvement, coupled with housing values I mean it's really consumer confidence game in terms of the opportunity for us. And we feel it. 
Let me just make a quick comment before we wrap up the call today. We have made significant progress add more favorably positioned the bank for the future. That's through specific actions we've taken during the quarter but really more broadly, through the benefits of some of our strategic operating decisions. We are building a more effective and efficient company, not only through expense savings but also in the way we're approaching revenue generation. A significant opportunity exist the loyalty that we have built and our team has the tools and training they need to uncover more client needs and further deepen those relationships. And that's not to say that the path ahead is not without its challenges, but there is a high level of intensity across of the organization translating opportunity and results. And I believe what we're focusing that energy and areas that can best impact bottom line performance. So with that said, thank you for joining us today and please reach out to our Investor Relations team with any other questions you may have.
